He had pancytopenia, decreased fibrinogen levels, increased ferritin levels, and increased circulating levels of soluble IL-2 receptor, meeting the clinical criteria for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH); Meningitis caused by vaccine-strain mumps was confirmed; he was hospitalized with fever, cough, and emesis occurring 7 days after vaccination with the measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella vaccines;   This literature marketed report has been received from the author of a published article referring to a 12-month-old male patient.  The patient was a nonconsanguineous boy with normal newborn screening results for severe combined immune deficiency (T-cell receptor excision circles, more than 252 copies/mL), was hospitalized 5 times in the first year of life with dehydration caused by common viral illnesses, including respiratory syncytial virus, norovirus, and coxsackie virus. At 12 months of age, he was hospitalized with fever, cough, and emesis occurring 7 days after vaccination with the measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella vaccines (manufacturer unknown) (strength, dose, frequency, route, lot# and expiration date were not reported) for prophylaxis (Contraindicated product administered). He rapidly had respiratory insufficiency and abdominopelvic ascites accompanied by diffuse adenopathy. Laboratory evaluation did not suggest a cellular or humoral immunodeficiency. He had pancytopenia, decreased fibrinogen levels, increased ferritin levels, and increased circulating levels of soluble IL-2 receptor, meeting the clinical criteria for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Meningitis caused by vaccine-strain mumps was confirmed by means of PCR of cerebral spinal fluid. High-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) treatment (2 g/kg) has been reported to be useful in the management of a STAT2-deficient patient with severe viral infections. Treatment of the patient with high-dose IVIG led to prompt resolution of HLH, with defervescence and normalization of ferritin levels and cell counts. He was subsequently started on IVIG (0.5 g/kg) every 3 weeks and avoids all live viral vaccines. The patient was 2 years old and had not had any further infections, hospitalizations, or episodes of HLH. Targeted next-generation sequencing of the patient's genomic DNA for 207 genes associated with primary immunodeficiency identified a novel homozygous splice donor variant in STAT2. His parents were heterozygous for the variant. No mutations were identified in other genes associated with primary HLH or primary immune deficiency. RT-PCR was performed on mRNA from EBV-transformed B-lymphoblastoid cell lines (BLCLs) from control subjects and the patient to determine whether the mutation affected STAT2 splicing. The 533-bp fragment surrounding the mutation site was identified in the control subject. In contrast, a lower molecular weight band of approximately 437 bp was identified in cDNA from the patient's BLCLs. Sanger sequencing demonstrated abnormal splicing in the patient's cDNA amplicon, resulting in deletion of exon 13 and in-frame splicing of exons 12 and 14. Immunoblotting of lysates from BLCLs demonstrated abrogation of STAT2 protein expression in the patient without expression of any truncated protein products. STAT2 deficiency in human subjects and mice is characterized by defective type I interferon signaling. The infection and subsequent transformation of B cells with EBV activates STAT2 and upregulates expression of interferon-stimulated genes, including IFIT1, ISG15, and IRF7, which are further increased after exposure to type I interferons. Expression of IFIT1, ISG15, and IRF7 was severely decreased in the patient's BLCLs compared with those from control subjects. Furthermore, the patient's BLCLs did not upregulate IFIT1, ISG15, and IRF7 after IFN-a stimulation, indicating a lack of STAT2-driven signaling in response to type I interferons. The outcome of haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and meningitis was reported as recovered. The reporter considered haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and meningitis to be related to measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella vaccines (manufacturer unknown).  Upon internal review, haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and meningitis were considered to be medically significant.  A copy of the published article is attached as further documentation of the patient's experience.

The patient was a nonconsanguineous boy with normal newborn screening results for severe combined immune deficiency (T-cell receptor excision circles, more than 252 copies/mL), was hospitalized 5 times in the first year of life with dehydration caused by common viral illnesses, including respiratory syncytial virus, norovirus, and coxsackie virus. He had pancytopenia, decreased fibrinogen levels, increased ferritin levels, and increased circulating levels of soluble IL-2 receptor, meeting the clinical criteria for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Meningitis caused by vaccine-strain mumps was confirmed by means of PCR of cerebral spinal fluid. The infection and subsequent transformation of B cells with EBV activates STAT2 and upregulates expression of interferon-stimulated genes, including IFIT1, ISG15, and IRF7, which are further increased after exposure to type I interferons. Expression of IFIT1, ISG15, and IRF7 was severely decreased in the patient's BLCLs compared with those from control subjects. Furthermore, the patient's BLCLs did not upregulate IFIT1, ISG15, and IRF7 after IFN-a stimulation, indicating a lack of STAT2-driven signaling in response to type I interferons. The outcome of haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and meningitis was reported as recovered. The reporter considered haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and meningitis to be related to measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella vaccines (manufacturer unknown). A copy of the published article is attached as further documentation of the patient's experience.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: No adverse effects reported; improperly stored vaccine was administered to patient; This spontaneous report as received from a nurse refers to a patient of unknown age and gender. No information regarding the patient's pertinent medical history, drug reactions or allergies and concomitant therapies was provided.  On an unknown date in July 2019 (reported as between 03-JUL-2019 and 29-JUL-2019), the patient was vaccinated with improperly stored dose of varicella virus vaccine live (oka/merck) (VARIVAX) lot # S002393, expiration date 31-JAN-2021 and lot # R035225, expiration date 04-DEC-2020 (dose and route of administration were not reported) for prophylaxis and improperly stored measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) lot # S003178, expiration date reported as 31-JUL-2020, but upon internal validation established as 30-JUL-2020 and lot # S008577, expiration date reported as 30-SEP-2020, but upon internal validation established as 16-SEP-2020 (dose and route of administration were not reported) for prophylaxis. There was no adverse effect reported. Administered doses of vaccines experienced the temperature excursion of total time in range -14 degrees Celsius to -10 degrees Celsius (-12.8 degrees Celsius) for 12 hours 3 minutes. There were no previous excursions reported. The data logger was involved.  This is one of several cases received from the same reporter.; Sender's Comments:  US-009507513-1908USA000192:

SYMPTOM_TEXT: No adverse effects reported.; PROQUAD administered/improperly stored; This non-valid spontaneous report was received from a registered nurse and refers to unspecified number of patients of unknown demographics. There was no information about the patients' concurrent conditions or medical histories provided. The patients' concomitant therapies included sterile diluent. Since an unknown day in June 2019, the patients were vaccinated with improperly stored doses of varicella virus vaccine live (oka/merck)(VARIVAX)(exact doses, route of administration, lot# and expiration date were not reported) and measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) (exact doses, route of administration, lot# and expiration date were not reported) for prophylaxis. The vaccines underwent temperature excursion of unknown temperature for unknown time frame. There were multiple previous temperature excursion since an unknown day in June 2019. The digital data logger was involved in recording excursion details. Diluent was reported to be stored properly. No adverse effects were reported.  Follow up information has been received from the nurse on 17-JUL-2019. On unknown dates, the patients were also vaccinated with improperly stored doses of Zoster Vaccine Live (ZOSTAVAX). The measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (Oka-Merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) (lot # R004440, expiry date 12-AUG-2019) were exposed to temperature between 47 degrees Fahrenheit (F) to 77 F (between 9 degrees Celsius to 25 degrees Celsius) for 135 hours and was administered to unspecified patients on 17-APR-2019, 18-APR-2019, 22-APR-2019, 23-APR-2019, 24-APR-2019, 30-APR-2019, 07-MAY-2019, 15-MAY-2019, 21-JUN-2019, 24-JUN-2019 and 25- JUN-2019. The varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck)(VARIVAX) (lot # S005080 and expiry date 19-FEB-2019) were exposed to temperature between 47 F to 77 F (between 9 degrees Celsius to 25 degrees Celsius) for 11 hours and 24 minutes. The varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck)(VARIVAX) (lot # R018777 and expiry date 01-JUL-2020) were exposed to temperature between 47 F to 77 F (between 9 degrees Celsius to 25 degrees Celsius) for 135 hours. The measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (Oka-Merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) (lot # R004440, expiry date 12-AUG-2019) were exposed to temperature between 6 F to 14 F (-14 C to -10 C) for 754 minutes and between 15 F to 46 F (-9 C to 8 C) for 41 minutes. The measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (Oka-Merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) (lot # S005074, expiry date 18-AUG-2020) were exposed to temperature between 6 F to 14 F (-14 C to -10 C) for 28 minutes and between 15 F to 46 F (-9 C to 8 C) for 32 minutes. The varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck)(VARIVAX) (lot # R006753 and expiry date 06-MAR-2020) were exposed to temperature between 6 F to 14 F (-14 C to -10 C) for 754 minutes and between 15 F to 46 F (-9 C to 8 C) for 41 minutes. The varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck)(VARIVAX) (lot # R027995 and expiry date 01-OCT-2020) were exposed to temperature between 6 F to 14 F (-14 C to -10 C) for 754 minutes and between 15 F to 46 F (-9 C to 8 C) for 41 minutes. The varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck)(VARIVAX) (lot # S000582 and expiry date 19-FEB-2021) were exposed to temperature between 6 F to 14 F (-14 C to -10 C) for 28 minutes and between 15 F to 46 F (-9 C to 8 C) for 32 minutes.  On 12-AUG-2019, a telephone call was received from the registered nurse. She stated that she was in the process of completing forms with identifiable patients' information. Additional information has been requested.  Upon receipt of follow-up information, it was determined that this case is now valid because the patient identifiers were reported. Follow up information from the nurse has been received on 12-AUG-2019, and refers to a 4-year-old male patient. On 25-JUN-2019, the patient was vaccinated with improperly stored dose of measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (Oka-Merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD).  There was no prescription drug treatment for the experience required.     This is one of multiple reports received from the same reporter.; Sender's Comments:  US-009597513-1908USA004972: US-009597513-1908USA004969: US-009597513-1907USA011162: US-009597513-1908USA005049: US-009597513-1908USA005032: US-009597513-1908USA005023: US-009597513-1908USA004985: US-009597513-1908USA004983: US-009597513-1908USA004922:

Grandfather called clinic on 8/16 with a report of granddaughter having a "rash" and redness to left leg and chest.  Description was "redness that started around neck and faded away at chest." Denied having individual lesions, nothing on head.  Did not come into clinic for staff to observe.  Staff encouraged grandfather to take granddaughter to Health Center for evaluation if rash worsened or if he had other concerns. He stated his wife was immunocompromised but didn't know why.  Reported hx of anaphylaxis reactions to soda ash.  Grandfather stated he would seek care if rash worsened.

Patient developed rash on 6/13/19 & a fever. Patient had white spots in mouth. Child said things tasted funny. Possible Thrush-given tx for Nystatin 100,000 unit/mL. Apply to white spots on tongue 4xdaily for 14 days. Given Benadryl for rash. Diffuse maculopapular rash face to feet, sparring palms & sole. Dept. of Health was called and Rapid Flu test - Negative. Mom advised patient needed testing for measles. The patients mom refused any testing and was very upset. She took her children and left the building w/out finishing the visit. Dept. of Health stated they would take it from here and follow up w/the patients parents.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: fever, swelling of face, eye pain and pressure in eyes, blood shot eyes, daily sneezing (1-4 times a day), nose stuffed, labored breathing noticed during sleep, sleepwalking (twice), speaking during dreams,loss of appetite, more clumsy, thinking more cloudy, thoughts of hopelessness, daily crying, profound sadness (only in the evening).     My daughter continues to have hopeless thoughts and sadness every evening that is relieved with crying and lasts from 30 min to one hour. It occurs when the sun is coming down. She still sneezes, but less.  Her eyes are bloodshot at night.
LAB_DATA: I am continuing to get testing. She took an antibody test. After only one shot the positive value for measles is greater than 29.99. My daughter's IGG is greater than 300. For rubella immunity is greater than 1. Her value is 16.80.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: I may have the brands off for the vaccines, I'm reading off of his past visit report. He had extreme pain in his legs, couldn't stand or walk for hours. He was screaming from around 9pm until 11:30pm from pain, I could not touch his injection site or hold him anywhere but around his chest without him screaming and shaking. he developed and fever of 105* around, we went to the ER and they said it was normal, it went down after Tylenol, but was back up to 105.6* at 5:30am. At 8:30am he had a fever of 104.4* and we went into his doctor, who found he had developed an ear infection "as a result of the vaccines". He had a low level fever until 8/23/19

Had vaccines on 8/6/19.  Presented back to clinic 8/8/19.  Mom states child did well with vaccines but the next day woke up complaining of soreness on left arm. She looked  and site was red and swollen and hot to touch.  She put ice to area on and off and says it does look better.  Today area on left upper arm is red, raised and hot to touch.  Measures 2.5  x 3 cm.  Advised to continue to apply ice on and off for next 24 hours.  Advised follow up with physician for eval.  today.   8/9/19:  Phoned mother.  She did take child to his physician and they gave him a steroid shot and oral prednisone and it looks much better now.  She states they did not call it allergic .
Rash from face to arms to trunk within seconds of receiving vaccines. Given Benadryl and resolved within 30 min.

1 day after immunization, pt noted redness, swelling, tenderness, and itching at injection site on right thigh.  Mildly antalgic gait. Received motrin at home for pain (afebrile).  On the next day, presented back to primary care office due to significant enlargement of areas of redness, swelling, and tenderness.  Area was >10-15 cm in diameter, red, warm, indurated, with pain to palpation.  Pt was afebrile (T 99F orally) but tachycardic to 130's (on prior visit, HR had been in 90s), although she was well-appearing.  Sent to ER for evaluation of possible cellulitis due to rapid spread and possible systemic Sx.  IV ancef given, pt was started on oral Keflex and advised to follow with PCP.  Follow up call placed by LPN on next day--parent reported swelling had improved though redness still present.  Appointment scheduled for follow up though pt did not arrive to visit.
LAB_DATA: CBC/diff (results not available at this time but reportedly reassuring), CRP (reportedly mildly elevated at 1.1)
HISTORY: BMI >95%tile History of febrile seizure (in or before 2017) Glucosuria with normal hemoglobin A1c

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Redness and swelling at the injection site; Redness and swelling at the injection site; This spontaneous report was received from a safety clinical coordinator refers to a 5 year old male patient. The patient's medical history, concurrent conditions and concomitant medications were unknown. On 13-AUG-2019, the patient was vaccinated with (therapy type rHA) measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) of one dosage form via subcutaneous route (lot # S006833, exp.date : 02-SEP-2020) for prophylaxis. Other suspect therapies included sterile diluent (DILUENT MRK INJ) of one dosage form (Lot No. N028746 has been verified to be a valid lot number for [sterile diluent], expiration date reported as 17-MAR-2020, but upon internal validation established as 10-MAR-2020). The patient immediately experienced injection site erythema and injection site swelling. The swelling was treated with Benadryl and ice. Exact diluent used to dilute the vaccine was unknown. The patient sought medical attention. No product quality issue was reported. The nurse reported that they are unable to point to specific lot of sterile diluent that was used for a specific vaccine. Sterile diluent was placed in a bin and vials are pulled as necessary from the bin to be used. The lot number for diluent was not recorded with a specific patient. The process has been changed. The four originally shared lot numbers for the diluent have been taken out of the bin, but it was not listed as product in the case product tab. The outcome for injection site swelling and injection site erythema was reported as recovered. The causality assessment between measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD)  and events was not reported.

No adverse effects were reported; Was administered a dose of VARIVAX and PROQUAD at the same visit; The patient was administered the first dose of PROQUAD too early; This spontaneous report was received from a medical assistant concerning a currently 12 year old patient. There was no information regarding the patient's medical history, concurrent conditions or concomitant medications.  On 05-NOV-2007, the patient was administered the first dose of measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live(PROQUAD) for prophylaxis too early (dose, frequency, route of administration, anatomical location, lot number and expiration date were not provided). Since measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live(PROQUAD) was administered too early it did not count on immunization records and the patient needed a dose of varicella and measles, mumps, and rubella (M-M-R II); instead, on 15-AUG-2019, the patient was vaccinated with the second dose of measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live rHA(PROQUAD) lot # S008577 with expiration date of 16-SEP-2020, for prophylaxis and with a dose of varicella virus vaccine live (oka/merck)(VARIVAX) lot # R017638 with expiration date of 20-JUN-2020) for prophylaxis (dose, frequency, route of administration and anatomical location were not reported for none of both vaccines). Both, measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live(PROQUAD) and varicella virus vaccine live (oka/merck)(VARIVAX) were reconstituted with sterile diluent(STERILE DILUENT) lot # N023666 with expiration date of 05-FEB-2020.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Varivax and Proquad was administered to the same patient at the same visit. The Medical Assistant who administered the immunizations did not know varicella was part of proquad. The parents of the patient was contacted and the patient had no adverse signs or symptoms. The Medical Assistant who administered the immunization received education on immunizations, was counseled on reading all labels, and participated in creating a label making it easy to identify between the MMRV and MMR to prevent this from happening in the future. The office will be educated on this.

Patient was seen at office for 4 year well child visit and given routine 4 year vaccines (MMRV, Quadracel) Patient was fine after the vaccinations and left the office. On the way to school mom states she was trying to get patient's attentions and he was passed out and he urinated on himself during the episode in the car.  Episode lasted 30 seconds. He dropped his head and during the episode his arms went up "like he was dabbing".  When they arrived here his lips were pale, he was awake and alert.  He was oriented in office with normal vitals.  He was observed for 10-15 minutes and was stating he wanted to go home.

Patient seen by PCP on 8/27/19 for Annual Physical. No illness at time of visit. Received MMRV  and DTap/IPV immunizations. On 8/29/19, Mom called triage line @ 10:25AM to report an immunization reaction. Child exhibited the expected symptoms: Fever and pain at the injection site. However, Mom also reported "vomiting once daily (twice total)", itchiness on the right arm, redness 2-3inches on the left arm. Child feels well, otherwise, eating and drinking normally. Mom agreed to clinical eval and was seen at the clinic the same day.  MD saw patient @ 10:40am.  Visit Diagnoses    Adverse effect of vaccine, initial encounter    -  Primary   Relevant Medications   triamcinolone (KENALOG) 0.1 % cream   I suspect a local reaction to his vaccine. The more significant reaction is the site of his MMRV on the right arm. He has now completed the series for MMR, Varicella, and polio. He should have Tdap when due in the future. Fever has resolved and I don't suspect infection at this time but I did draw a circle around each area of erythema and asked mom to watch carefully. Follow up if he redevelops fever or if erythema is increasing. Antihistamines, ice pack, and topical triamcinolone cream also recommended.   Patient Instructions Claritin or Zyrtec 5 mg daily for the next 3 days, then as needed. Continue ice pack to the affected area twice daily for 10 minutes. Benadryl 25 mg at bedtime if needed for itching. Triamcinolone cream to the affected area 3 times daily until improved. Follow up if area of swelling/erythema worsening tomorrow or recurrent fever.       Return in about 10 days (around 9/8/2019) for recheck if not improving..  Subjective: Patient is a 5 y.o. male who presents today with mom with concerns about vaccine reaction. The patient had vaccines two days ago. He had the vaccines at 9 AM on Tuesday. By Tue night he had fever. Mom reports fever was high but she didn't check a temperature. He had one episode of emesis on Tue and one on Wed. No fever since last night. He has usually had fever every time he has had vaccines but this has been worse. She also noticed swelling and itching at the injection sites this morning. Activity and appetite normal today.

No adverse effect reported; Names of vaccines involved: PROQUAD; This spontaneous report was received from a licensed vocational nurse reporting on a patient of unknown age and gender. There was no information about the patient's concurrent conditions, medical history or concomitant medication.  On 14-AUG-2019, the patient received an improperly stored dose of measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (Oka-Merck) Virus Vaccine Live rHA (PROQUAD) 0.5 mL, for prophylaxis lot number R022566 and expiration date 04-FEB-2020 (anatomical location and route of administration were not reported) which was diluted with sterile diluent. No adverse effects reported.  It was reported that on an unspecified date, the vaccine was exposed to a temperature between 47 Fahrenheit degrees and 77 Fahrenheit degrees for 11 hours and 30 minutes. The vaccine was also exposed to a temperature between 6 Fahrenheit degrees and 14 Fahrenheit degrees for 30 minutes; and in the recommended frozen range between 58 Fahrenheit degrees and 5 Fahrenheit degrees for 30 minutes (conflicting information). The call was placed because of a Digital Data logger report.
Swollen face, headache, malaise, measles like rash covering large portions of her body including her stomach, back, face, both arms and legs and buttocks

Patient developed fever, spreading erythema, swelling, one small blister, and induration over right thigh 1 day after receiving immunizations. Admitted for observation, with improvement of erythema, swelling, and induration and resolution of fever after receiving 3 doses of IV clindamycin. Patient was discharged home on PO clindamycin x 7 days for R thigh cellulitis.
LAB_DATA: CBC (8/31): WBC 10.1, Hgb 12.3, Hct 37.3, Plt 364, Neutrophils 60, Lymph 30, Monocytes 6, Eosinophils 4 Blood culture (8/31): no growth as of 9/1 at 1111

SYMPTOM_TEXT: 2 seizures less than 8 hours after. My son seized for about 2 minutes, stopped breathing, and fever spiked to 102 degrees. 2nd seizure less than 45 minutes after 1st while in hospital. Again stopped breathing, full body seizure, fever at 102 degrees.

?Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) is a disease involving inflammation of small blood vessels. It most commonly occurs in children. The inflammation causes blood vessels in the skin, intestines, kidneys, and joints to start leaking. The main symptom is a rash with numerous small bruises, which have a raised appearance, over the legs or buttocks.  Although HSP can affect people at any age, most cases occur in children between the ages of 2 and 11. It is more common in boys than girls. Adults with HSP are more likely to have more severe disease compared to children.  HSP usually ends after four to six weeks -- sometimes with recurrence of symptoms over this period, but with no long-term consequences (recurrences are fairly common). If organs such as the kidneys and intestines are affected, treatment is often needed and it is important to have regular follow-up to prevent serious complications.  The exact cause of HSP is not known. The body's immune system is believed to play a role in targeting the blood vessels involved. An abnormal immune response to an infection may be a factor in many cases. Approximately two-thirds of the cases of HSP occur days after symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection develop.  Some cases of HSP have been linked to vaccinations for typhoid, cholera, yellow fever, measles, or hepatitis B; foods, drugs, chemicals, and insect bites. Some experts also say that HSP is associated with the colder weather of fall and winter.  HSP can cause kidney problems, indicated by such signs as protein or blood in the urine. This is usually only discovered on urine testing, since it does not generally cause any discomfort.  In most patients, the kidney impairment is mild and goes away without any long-term damage. It's important to monitor the kidney problems closely and make sure they clear up, since about 5% of patients may develop progressive kidney disease. About 1% may go on to develop total kidney failure.?  Patient, 4 years old, had to have her vaccines to start Pre-K , so on 8/06/19 she got her vaccinations. Then last Saturday, 8/24/19, she developed a bad cough. She wasn?t better by Monday so we did not send her to school and she went to her doctor that Tuesday, 8/27/19. She was then treated for an upper respiratory infection and had a follow up appointment that Thursday, 8/29/19. We got a call from the school saying she couldn?t bare any weight on her legs and that she had really bad bruising on her legs. She was fine when she got on the bus. Long story short...we get to the ER and after a CT, X-ray, and CBC she was diagnosed with HSP.   From Thursday to Friday her blood pressure was very high and she had blood in her urine. She had bruising from her buttocks to her toes and her palms were bruised. Doctors were in and out like crazy checking blood pressure and examining her joints and the new bruises that were appearing on her legs and feet and even on her hands. She complained that her stomach hurt, her head hurt, her legs hurt, and everyone seemed to be at a loss.  Around 4pm on Friday she still could not walk or move her legs at all and the swelling and bruising had not dissipated. She would scream because the pain in her legs was unbearable. She wanted to take a bath around 4:30 and we thought it would help her joints to sit in a hot bath. She could only bare weight for maybe 5 seconds without crying and saying it hurt. About an hour later she started moving her feet and toes, then bending her knees, and then moving her legs.  Then about 30 minutes later she needed to pee and actually walked back to the bed from the bathroom. Then started bossing people around and wanted to stand and sing us a song. My typical bossy patient! She went to the foot of the bed and started sing. We all started to cry. Prayer works in case you didn?t know.  Saturday morning we thought her IV went bad because her left arm started showing signs of swelling but no bruises. Then we literally sat there and watched her arms start to have bruising appear as she slept. Her swelling was so bad they had to remove her hospital band because it was digging into her skin. Her legs that morning were not as swollen and she seemed to not be in as much pain. The doctors were still worried about her kidney functions and her high blood pressure. We still are not out of the woodwork yet with that.   Thankfully today at 3 yesterday (Sunday) we were able to go home. We still have many months of follow ups to do to check her blood pressure and to do urinalysis to check for protein and blood in her urine and we still have to monitor her input and output. Prayers are still greatly needed and appreciated.  This is a very rare thing that can happen to your little one and I was scared out of my mind with what could be causing this type of reaction. It affected her skin, intestines, kidneys, joints, and now we have at least 4 months of weekly checkups until she is in the clear. Hopefully sooner.   Please SHARE this to let people know that this could happen if your child has had shots (MMR) and then recently received medical attention for an upper respiratory problem. It was the perfect storm for her to get it. There is not much known about the why or how exactly a child contracts this but it can have lifelong affects. Prayers it does not with patient. This was not her first time getting treated for an upper respiratory problem or getting vaccines. But for whatever reason now she has HSP which had this response that is known to be linked to the MMR vaccine.   She had no signs of it when she got on the bus and it didn?t take long to progress and just as quickly it dissipated.  Thanks for taking the time to read this and share. Maybe it will get around to enough people that it will get some awareness and help another child get medical attention sooner.

Presented with non-pruritic urticaria scattered on trunk and arms with right ankle swelling and pain. Mother gave Benadryl 5mL the evening that hives appeared which provided relief. On exam on 8/31/19: wheals scattered on back of leg, abdomen, flank - flat, raised wheals on inner right arm.  erythema of anterior right ankle, no swelling or pain. Ankle erythema may have been secondary to irritation from tight shoes that she wore that day. Spoke to mother on 9/2/19, rash gradually resolved after office visit. No further doses of Benadryl.

It was reported that the temperature excursion was noticed by the digital data logger and that the temperature excursion was for 3 hours from -9 to 8 degrees Celsius. There was no previous temperature excursion. No adverse effects were reported.  Follow-up information has been received on 28-AUG-2019. A phone call was placed to the medical assistant. The phone call was answered by the receptionist. The C.M.A was unavailable. A message was left requesting a return phone call. Additionally, a request was made for patient identifiers, lot and vaccine received and on what date.  Follow up information had been received on 29-AUG-2019. A returned phone call was received from the medical assistant. The patient was a 4 years old female. On 26-NOV-2018, she was vaccinated with improperly stored varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) (lot # R012413, expiration date 28-OCT-2019, strength, dose and route were unknown) for prophylaxis.  Upon receipt of follow-up information it was determined that this case now is valid, because the patient identifier was provided. On Friday August 9th patient had her vaccines done. I was against the vaccines but my husband and I had decided to change our minds, and lean towards getting them for her. On 8/12 I took my daughter back to the doctor because she had started wheezing and seemed sick. The NP prescribed a steroid called predinose that I know my child will refuse to take and will literally spit it out because it is so disgusting. I asked NP to prescribe her the disintegrating tabs but my insurance wouldn't pay for it. Patient had seemed to be getting better on her own, so I left it alone and did not give her any medicine. I was thinking she is just having a minor cold and will clear up on her own as she has before. On 8/27 I put her to bed, but at about 5:30 am on 8/28 I rushed her to the hospital as I could tell her breathing was getting worse and she was not responding to breathing treatments. She was admitted  for 3 days and two nights. The did an x-ray and said she had pneumonia in her right lung, which I recall being one of the possible side effects of the MMRV vaccine. She had a nose swab done and it came back positive for rhinovirus. I do not know if the vaccine caused this to happen, but I believe that it did since she was a healthy child before the vaccines.

7 or 8 days after the MMR vaccine, my daughter developed a very high fever (104.5), cough, and rash all over her body. We called her physician and she said it was normal and to call back if she still had a high fever in 2 days. 2 days later, her fever was still very high (103-104) and the rash was way worse and my daughter was very lethargic, weeping, not very responsive. I was scared and called her physician again. They said she might have measles and to bring her into the clinic through the back stairwell. She had blood work and the Department of  Health was contacted. They determined she did have a severe case of  measles and it was the exact strain from her vaccine (not wild-caught measles). We were told we had to be quarantined in our home for 7 days and to keep an eye out for secondary infections/illness. My daughter then developed an ear infection in both ears, which I treated her for at home naturally. Immediately after this episode, my daughter who had no behavioral or developmental issues, began having a really hard time at school and was sent home for aggressive behavior. We went to see a behavioral therapist to be evaluated and they determined she had ADHD and Sensory Processing Disorder. These behavioral issues literally happened overnight and prior to this vaccine had no indications of behavioral issues.
LAB_DATA: She had bloodwork done in the clinic that was sent off to the lab through department of health to determine weather she had ?wild-caught? or vaccine acquired measles.

Pt has redness, swelling, and several pimple size fluid blisters on the left deltoid.  The skin is tight along the entire left upper arm.  The redness and swelling when measured is 16cm x 14cm.  Mom states the child complained about it hurting.  Child has no fever.   Cold compresses have been applied for 20 minutes at a time as tolerated.  Tylenol and Motrin have been alternated for pain.  Child is moving arm around with no issues and does not display pain at the time of observation.   Area was marked and instructed mom to watch area and to let us know if the redness extends beyond the markings.  Instructed to continue the compresses.

She had her vaccine late evening on September 11th.  The next morning when she woke up she said her leg hurt and it hurt to walk. I just told her she would be fine.  Then I looked at her leg  when I got her dressed. It was a little swollen (which I expected) a little red and warm to the touch. She had a slight fever of 99.8.  She went to school and I picked her up at 11:30.  Her leg looked much worse. I called the dr office and they told me to put cold compress on the site and give her motrin.  I went back to work and an hour later I received a call that my daughter is really hurting. She is saying her head hurts and is not herself at all.  I called back the dr and got an apt to go in.  I saw a nurse for about 2 mins max. She looked at her leg and just said it was normal. No vitals were taken.  On the way home I stopped to pick up motrin from the store and gave it to her in the parking lot.  I picked up my son and we went home. When I got home I took her temp again (after I gave her motrin).  It was almost 103.  By that evening (5:00pm) Her whole upper thigh was huge.  Over the size of a baseball.  It was very red and very hot to the touch.  The next morning 9/13 there was no change in her leg.  Her fever was down to the upper 100's with no Motrin given.  She still said her leg hurt to walk.  On 9/14 the swelling went down slightly but was still very red and hot to the touch.  She no longer had a fever.  That evening she developed diarrhea.  9/15 she still had diarrhea that morning. Her leg was still red and  hot to the touch.  The swelling did go down a little more.  9/16 No diarrhea. The swelling continues to go down along with the redness.  It is no longer hot to the touch.
CUR_ILL: She had a cold a week prior to vaccine

the patient was inadvertently administered one dose of PROQUAD on 17-JUL-2019; The titers for varicella were less than 0.9, which the nurse reported as being negative titers to those diseases; The titers for rubeola were less than 0.6, which the nurse reported as being negative titers to those diseases; Information has been received from a registered nurse referring to a 19 years old male patient. Information of concomitant therapy, pertinent medical history and drug reactions/allergies was not reported.  On 01-SEP-2000, the patient received one dose of varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck) (VARIVAX) (batch/lot #, expiration date, strength, dose and route were unknown) for prophylaxis. On 10-NOV-2000, he received one dose of Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (Wistar RA 27-3) Virus Vaccine, Live (M-M-R II) (batch/lot #, expiration date, strength, dose and route were unknown) for prophylaxis. On 12-JUL-2004, he received another dose of Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (Wistar RA 27-3) Virus Vaccine, Live (M-M-R II) (batch/lot #, expiration date, strength, dose and route were unknown). On 24-MAY-2010, he received another of varicella virus vaccine live (Oka/Merck) (VARIVAX) (batch/lot #, expiration date, strength, dose and route were unknown).  On 12-JUN-2019, the patient had titers drawn because he was going to school to be a certified medical assistant, and titers were required. The titers for rubeola were less than 0.6 (unit not provided), and for varicella were less than 0.9 (unit not provided), which the nurse reported as being negative titers to those diseases (measles antibody negative, antibody test negative). Because of that, on 17-JUL-2019, the patient was inadvertently administered one dose of Measles, Mumps, Rubella and Varicella (Oka-Merck) Virus Vaccine Live (PROQUAD) (1 dose, batch/lot # S003173, expiration date: 30-JUL-2020, strength and route were unknown) for prophylaxis (inappropriate age at vaccine administration). Medical attention was sought to the physician. The outcome of the events was unknown.  The causality between the vaccines and the events was not provided.
LAB_DATA: Test Date: 20190612; Test Name: The titers for rubeola; Test Result: Negative

HPI: erythematous site to RT thigh after receiving immunizations 2 days ago. Pt received MMR/VAR and DTAP/IPV on 9/17/19 and has since developed a pruritic, warm and red lesion to site where INJ were given. Mother has not given an antihistamines in response to reaction. Mother denies any angioedema, difficulty breathing or swallowing. PLAN:  pt may take prednisone <20 mg day <14 days for adverse reaction to live virus vaccine. Will treat adverse reaction with prednisone 5 mg daily x 5 days. Instructed mother to continue Benadryl as needed. Monitor reaction site and notify clinic if borders increase or systemic reaction occurs. Apply cool compresses to site. Encouraged mother to continue with Hep B immunization in one month. Risks vs benefits discussed. Adverse reaction reported to vaccine manufacturer. Mother v/u.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Within 5 minutes of receiving vaccine began sneezing abdundantly, then became lethargic, which progressed to listlessness and decreased responsiveness. Retracting, wheezing, hypoxic (sats dropped into 60s), arms and face flushed, grunting. Received oxygen, albuterol and atrovent via nebulizer, epinephrine 0.15 mg IM then 0.3 mg IM 10 minutes later, oral dexamethasone, IM benadryl and transported to Emergency Room. By time transported, oxygen saturations had improved to low 90s. Report from ER that was sitting up, alert and interactive within an hour. Kept overnight for observation.
LAB_DATA: Will refer to allergist after recovered from this event
CUR_ILL: mild nasal congestion discussed at time of visit thought to be possible seasonal allergies

SYMPTOM_TEXT: no adverse event; The patient received a dose of improperly stored PROQUAD; This spontaneous report was received from a medical assistant concerning a patient of unknown age and gender. No information was provided regarding the patient's pertinent medical history, concurrent conditions or drug reactions/allergies.     On 19-SEP-2019, the patient was vaccinated with an improperly stored dose of Measles, Mumps, Rubella and Varicella (Oka-Merck) Virus Vaccine Live (PROQUAD), via subcutaneous for vaccination lot number S013715 and expiration date 01-NOV-2020 (strength, dose and frequency) (product storage error). The vaccine was reconstituted with Merck sterile diluent that did not experience a temperature excursion (lot number and expiration date were not reported).  The administered dose of the vaccine experienced a temperature excursion range of 6°F to 14°F(14F) for 3 hours and a range of range of 15°F to 46°F (27F) for 11 hours. The vaccine experienced a previous temperature excursion of 15°F to 46°F (38F) for 51 hours.  There was no adverse effect reported.

Approximately 20 minutes after vaccine administration, patient developed generalized urticarial.  No respiratory or GI symptoms.  Re-evaluated in the office, normal cardiac and lung exam.  Diffuse urticarial and pruritus.  Given 5mg PO chewable Claritin and applied topical triamcinolone.  MOC called back about 3 hours later and symptoms had resolved.

Patient was vaccinated in exam room and after 5 minutes patient was instructed to walk to the lab for additional testing.  The lab assistant  heard a knock on the wall and looked out into the hallway when she witnessed patient falling to floor.  She grabbed patient in time before he hit the floor.  The patient was quickly examined by physician who reports he had a tonic clonic seizure for 5-10 seconds.  The patient awoke after seizure and vital done (wnl) and juice was given.  The patient was brought back to room and assessed.  He was sent to ER for evaluation given neurologic sx after head injury.

Per Mother:  Leg started to look red and swollen on Saturday. Pt also started to develop a cough today. Mild fever on Friday and given Tylenol with improvement. Pt is stating that when she walks it hurts.  Per Dr.  "Leg swelling on the left thigh near insertion of the immunization needle with erythematous, warm and swollen thigh. Nonperulent in nature and causing some purities and pain with movement. Mother edu that this is likely a bacterial infection therefore will treat empirically with Keflex 4ml Q6hrs for 10 days (due to non purulence) and will have close follow up."
LAB_DATA: Per Dr. "Due to pain with movement we will get ultrasound to R/O thrombophibitis vs abscess vs less likely DVT" Referral for U/S needs to be finalized. Pt will be contacted to make appt.

Patient received 1 year vaccines. Next day, started itching  severely, had fever of 101, and runny nose.  Fever continued to Sunday; alternated Tylenol and Ibuprofen to control it.   Rash started on face, then on elbow creases and then his legs.  Red dots like chickenpox now spread all over body from head to toes.  Patient went to the doctor today and doctor confirmed it was varicella and prescribed Prednisone. Clinic recommended a visit to Pediatrician and Allergist.  Patient doing well, with red bumps all over and itching a lot; looking out for scratching to avoid infection.
PRIOR_VAX: MMR: loss of appetite, started itching, fever for 1 week, rash would go away.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: That evening - severe bloody nose - fever of 104 as measured by home thermometer.  Fever, nose bleeds, lethargic behavior for subsequent days.  June 17th (5th day) morning - unable to stand (bare weight) on legs.   In months following, recurrent inability to stand/walk.  Approximately six months following, neurological symptoms including chorea, head bobbing, dysphagia, ataxia.
LAB_DATA: Xrays of legs and hips (6/17/18), CBC (July 2018), ANA (positive Dec 2018), Creatine Kinase (elevated Dec 2018), Swallow study (Jan 2019), Xrays of knees and ankles (Feb 2019), Bone marrow aspiration (Feb 2019), Lyme Disesase Blood Tests (Feb 2019), MRI of Brain (April 2019), MRI with contrast of Brain (April 2019), EEG (April 2019), Spinal Tap (June 2019), MRI of Brain (June 2019), MRI of Spine (June 2019), Ultrasound of Joints - Hips, Knees, Ankles (Sept 2019).

LAB_DATA: Xrays of legs and hips (6/17/18), CBC (July 2018), ANA (positive Dec 2018), Creatine Kinase (elevated Dec 2018), Swallow study (Jan 2019), Xrays of knees and ankles (Feb 2019), Bone marrow aspiration (Feb 2019), Lyme Disesase Blood Tests (Feb 2019), MRI of Brain (April 2019), MRI with contrast of Brain (April 2019), EEG (April 2019), Spinal Tap (June 2019), MRI of Brain (June 2019), MRI of Spine (June 2019), Ultrasound of Joints - Hips, Knees, Ankles (Sept 2019).

The patient was meant to have Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (M-M-R) administered instead of inadvertently being administered Measles, Mumps, Rubella and Varicella (Oka-Merck) Virus Vaccine Live (PROQUAD) (wrong product administered). no adverse effect; improperly stored doses of proquad; This spontaneous report was received from a nurse refers to a patient of unknown age and gender. Other suspect therapies included sterile diluent and it was unknown if the sterile diluent was stored properly (product storage error). By the time patient got home there was a red spot vaccination site raised like a giant welt.  Contacted doctor and vaccine administrator and was told that reaction was somewhat expected.  On Friday, contacted both facilities since it got worse.   Patient did not have fever and used cold compress but did not take any medication; treatment did not help welt doubled in size by next day.  By afternoon, welt was over 3 inches in diameter.  Contacted both facilities and told to keep watching it for changes, to treat fever with Motrin and give Benadryl if itching.  On Saturday, fever was 101.8, welt spread to size of palm.  Contacted Pediatrician and took patient to Urgent Care since fever kept rising; diagnosis was cellulitis.    Patient prescribed Bactrim. Affected area had expanded to 3 inches up from elbow.  Patient told to keep area clean and dry.  By next day, redness decreased to a milder pink color. Redness resolved within 48 hours.   Fever resolved since Sunday.   Notified Pediatrician that patient was on medication. Today patient is feeling much better; almost back to normal except for a little bruise at vaccination site. Area a little itchy but is not horrible.  Patient took Benadryl on Saturday night and last night.
OTHER_MEDS: Zyrtec, steroid nasal spray as needed, Magnesium, fiber, L-Theanine
HISTORY: Ichthyosis genetic mutation, autism, joint hyper mobility syndrome, Hypotonia
PRIOR_VAX: just a little sick after previous doses but nothing major
ALLERGIES: Red dye 40, severe dust allergy, lactose, amoxicillin

SYMPTOM_TEXT: patient developed soreness at the injection site; Information has been received from a physician referring to a 5 years old female patient. The patient had no medical history, no concurrent condition, no drug allergies or concomitant medications.  On 16-OCT-2019, the patient was vaccinated with measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (oka-merck) virus vaccine live (PROQUAD) (dose, strength, lot#, expiration date were unknown) and sterile diluent(STERILE DILUENT) (dose, strength, lot#, expiration date were unknown) subcutaneously into her inner upper thigh for prevention of measles, mumps, rubella and chicken pox.  On the same date, the patient experienced soreness at the injection site. On 17-OCT-2019, the patient came to physician's office and the patient recovered from the event. No treatment was given for the event. No lab diagnostics/studies were performed. The causality was unknown by reporter.

She developed a raised, hard, red, itchy bump at the injection site the day of the injection. She complained about it hurting and itching. By Saturday morning, the bump was 2 1/2 inches in diameter, warm to the touch, and she was in a lot of pain. We took her to the doctor who prescribed an antibiotic (Cephalexin) and 5ml of Zyrtec.  She recovered over the course of a week, but she still has discoloration- what looks like a large bruise at the site as of today (which is 3 1/2 weeks after the shot was given).  She does not have pain at the site any longer and it does not itch.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Our son was 1 years old at the time of this vaccine and he was hitting every milestone and a completely normal child, babbling and cooing and starting to talk. After the vaccine, he slept for an entire day and woke up and hasn't talked since. He has been seen by various doctors and specialists and now diagnosed with CAS - childhood apraxia of speech.

About 9 months after receiving these vaccines, my son started having chronic joint and muscle pain in right thigh/groin area.  The pain was so debilitating, he was often unable to walk,  he would limp or crawl due to pain.  Almost a year later and after extensive testing,  a muscle biopsy revealed Macrophages and Aluminum crystals striated throughout my son?s right thigh muscle, in the same area her received his vaccines.  The biopsy results showed that my son has Macrophagic Myofasciitis (MMF),  caused by the aluminum in his 2017 DTaP vaccine.  He has chronic, debilitating pain that has spread throughout his body and now he also has pain in both legs, arms, feet and hands.  He?s been living with this pain for almost two years.
LAB_DATA: Oct 2018 - inflammation blood panel Nov 2018 - x-ray of hip/groin/right leg April 2019 - inflammation blood panel and autoimmune work up May 2019 - MRI (showed inflammation in thigh muscles of both legs, with more inflammation in right leg) July 2019 - Muscle Biopsy (positive for Macrophagic Myofasciitis MMF) September 2019- specialized inflammation blood panel

11/15/19 Prior to imms. pt's temp was 98.8F per 2 different thermometers. After imms was administered, pt had gotten off exam table for dad to help her with putting on her coat. Pt slumped & became limp as dad was lifting her. Pt never lost consciousness, but became limp, pale, & unresponsive to verbal commands for aprox 30-40 seconds. No sz activity was noted & pt had her eyes open the entire time. Pt was placed on exam table & help was called. Pt immediately became responsive verbally & physically and color returned to her face. Pt was A&Ox3. Vitals @ 2:37pm were: B/P 82/64, temp 98.5F, HR 82, O2 98% & blood sugar 108. Pt's dad stated that "the same thing happened to me after getting my blood drawn in college & they found that I had a heart murmur. But it hasn't happened since then." Pt was evaluated by FNP & no heart murmur was noted. Dad stated that pt "had a late lunch & candy" when asked when had pt last eaten. Both writer & FNP stated & stressed importance of pt eating a meal with protein & less sugar after leaving clinic & pt being evaluated by her primary physician & or urgent care center asap. Dad verbalized understanding. At aprox 2:50pm, writer assisted pt & dad to check out & pt was noted to be walking independently & playing down the hallway by jumping from tile to tile to "avoid stepping on the tile cracks". 11/18/19 FU PC to dad. Dad stated pt was "sick all weekend with her temp going up to 102 degrees", however, she was given Tylenol & fever went down. Dad states that her mother "is currently taking care of her." Writer strongly urged either him or pt's (M) to take pt to her primary pediatrician or urgent care today to be evaluated. Dad verbalized understanding & stated that pt's "mother is supposed to be taking care of that." Dad states that pt has been "jumping around" & playing despite being sick & denies any further problems or needs @ this time.
CUR_ILL: Per dad, pt had a cold a few days before
